abstract: Dodgeball may be dead, but Google is back with a new service, Latitude, that lets smartphone users share their whereabouts with their friends.
snippet: Dodgeball may be dead, but Google is back with a new service, Latitude, that lets smartphone users share their whereabouts with their friends.
lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks after Google announced that it was terminating its Dodgeball service, which allowed cellphone users to share their current locations with their friends, the company is coming out Wednesday with a new service, Latitude, that, well, lets cellphone users share their locations with their friends.

headline.main: Where Are You? Show ‘Em With Google Latitude

abstract: Google notified Time Warner that it wants out of its 5 percent investment in AOL.
snippet: Google notified Time Warner that it wants out of its 5 percent investment in AOL.
lead_paragraph: Measured strictly in terms of financial returns, Google’s investment in AOL has been a dud. In 2005, Google paid $1 billion for a 5 percent stake in AOL, valuing the Time Warner unit at $20 billion. Last month, Google wrote down the value of that investment by $726 million, which assumes AOL’s new valuation is $5.5 billion.

headline.main: Google Wants Out of AOL Investment
